revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=April 2015}} {{Coord|40.91741|-73.125955|region:US_type:edu|display=title}}{{Infobox venue | name = Island Federal Credit Union Arena | nickname = | logo_image = | logo_caption = | image =[[File:Stony Brook Arena.jpg|300px]] | caption = The Island Federal Arena on a men's basketball conference game | fullname = | former_names = | location = John S. Toll Drive, [[Stony Brook, New York|Stony Brook]], New York, 11790 | coordinates = | broke_ground = | built = | opened = 1990 | renovated = 2012–2014 | demolished = | owner = [[State University of New York]] | operator = [[Stony Brook University]] | surface = | scoreboard = | cost = $17 million | architect = | capacity = 4,160 | record_attendance = | tenants = [[Stony Brook Seawolves]] (1990–present) | website = [http://www.goseawolves.org/school-bio/ston-10-arena.html www.goseawolves.org] }}
The '''Island Federal Credit Union Arena''', also known as the '''Island Federal Arena'''<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://stonybrookathletics.com/news/2018/11/30/mens-basketball-seawolves-bobcats-set-for-saturday-night-clash-at-the-island.aspx|title=Seawolves, Bobcats Set For Saturday Night Clash at The Island - Stony Brook University Athletics|work=Stony Brook University Athletics|access-date=2018-12-02|language=en-US}}</ref> or '''The Island<ref name=":0" />''', formerly the '''Stony Brook University Arena''', is 4,000-seat multi-purpose arena in [[Stony Brook, New York]]. It is the home of the [[Stony Brook Seawolves]] men's and women's basketball teams. Originally built in 1990, it underwent a $21.1 million renovation in 2012–14. Naming rights were sold to a regional credit union, Island Federal Credit Union.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.sbstatesman.com/2014/10/30/corporate-partnership-gives-stony-brook-arena-a-new-name/|title=Corporate partnership gives Stony Brook Arena a new name|last=Eichenholz|first=Andrew|work=The Statesman|access-date=2018-12-03|language=en-US}}</ref> The Island Federal Arena has hosted the [[America East Conference Men's Basketball Tournament]] finals in 2012 and 2016.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://nypost.com/2012/03/11/stony-brook-loses-america-east-final/|title=Stony Brook loses America East final|date=2012-03-11|work=New York Post|access-date=2018-12-02|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://stonybrookathletics.com/news/2016/3/12/Seawolves_punch_ticket_to_NCAA_tournament_with_80_74_win_over_Vermont.aspx|title=Seawolves punch ticket to NCAA tournament with 80-74 win over Vermont - Stony Brook University Athletics|work=Stony Brook University Athletics|access-date=2018-12-02|language=en-US}}</ref>
It contains four scoreboards and two videoboards, plus four luxury suites with 16 seats each.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://stonybrookathletics.com/sports/2016/8/25/facilities-ston-10-arena-html.aspx|title=Island Federal Credit Union Arena|website=Stony Brook University Athletics|language=en-US|access-date=2018-12-02}}</ref> It is also used for [[concerts]], [[trade show]]s, [[Convention (meeting)|convention]]s, graduations and other special events.
==Renovations==
A $21.1 million renovation of the Stony Brook University Arena was announced with $20 million provided by the State of New York and an additional $1 million provided by private donations.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://stonybrookathletics.com/news/2012/5/21/Stony_Brook_commences_21_1_million_Stony_Brook_Arena_renovation.aspx|title=Stony Brook commences $21.1 million Stony Brook Arena renovation - Stony Brook University Athletics|work=Stony Brook University Athletics|access-date=2018-12-02|language=en-US}}</ref> It included a [[seating capacity]] for 4,008 spectators, four luxury boxes and a VIP lounge area at the lodge level with premium courtside seating. During the renovations, both basketball teams played at [[Pritchard Gymnasium]], which like the IFCU Arena, is part of the [[Stony Brook Sports Complex]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://americaeast.com/news/2008/4/15/1440370.aspx|title=Stony Brook Unveils Plans to Renovate Basketball Arena|access-date=2018-12-03|language=en}}</ref> The renovation of the Arena was completed in 2014, and hosted its first home basketball game on November 14, 2014. Stony Brook defeated Columbia 57–56 on a game-winning layup.<ref>http://www.newsday.com/sports/college/stony-brook/stony-brook-to-begin-21-1m-arena-renovation-1.3728108</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://stonybrookathletics.com/news/2014/11/14/McGrew_s_game_winner_opens_Seawolves_season_and_new_arena_with_a_bang.aspx|title=McGrew's game-winner opens #Seawolves season and new arena with a bang - Stony Brook University Athletics|work=Stony Brook University Athletics|access-date=2018-12-03|language=en-US}}</ref> The arena reopened with a [[Harlem Globetrotters]] game.
==Gallery== <gallery> File:Stony Brook Arena.jpg File:Stony Brook Arena 2.jpg File:Stony Brook Arena 3.jpg File:Seawolves fans.jpg File:2016 AE championship.jpg File:Stony Brook Arena Seating Chart.jpg </gallery>
==See also== * [[List of NCAA Division I basketball arenas]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.stonybrookathletics.com/stonybrookarena/ Island Federal Credit Union Arena at stonybrookathletics.com]

{{about|the documentary|the song|Jimmy's Winning Matches}} {{Infobox television | show_name = Jimmy's Winnin' Matches | image = | caption = | show_name_2 = | genre = Documentary | creator = | developer = | writer = | director = Joanne McGrath | creative_director = | starring = [[Jim McGuinness]] | voices = | narrated = | theme_music_composer = | opentheme = | endtheme = | composer = | country = Ireland | language = | executive_producer = | producer = Joanne McGrath | editor = Michael Harte | location = | cinematography = Emmet Harte,
Brendan Bradas O'Donnell | camera = | runtime = 1 hour | company = | distributor = | channel = | picture_format = | audio_format = | first_run = | first_aired = | last_aired = | preceded_by = | followed_by = | related = | website = | website_title = | production_website = }} '''''Jimmy's Winnin' Matches''''' is an hour-long documentary which followed the success of the [[Donegal GAA|Donegal senior football team]] that won the [[2012 All-Ireland Senior Football Championship Final]] under the guidance of [[Jim McGuinness]]. It take its name from "[[Jimmy's Winning Matches]]", the anthem of Donegal's 2012 Championship success. It first aired on [[RTÉ One]] on 3 January 2013 at 9.35 pm.{{cite news|url=http://www.hoganstand.com/Donegal/ArticleForm.aspx?ID=182833|title=Donegal documentary on RTÉ|work=Hogan Stand|date=20 December 2012|accessdate=20 December 2012}}{{cite news|first=Conor|last=Heneghan|url=http://www.joe.ie/gaa/gaa-news/video-tuning-into-jimmys-winnin-matches-tonight-heres-a-teaser-clip-0032278-1|title=Tuning into Jimmy's Winnin' matches tonight? Here's a teaser clip|work=JOE.ie|date=3 January 2013|accessdate=3 January 2013}} Coco Television were responsible for putting it together.{{cite news|url=http://www.donegaldaily.com/2013/01/02/rte-to-show-donegals-all-ireland-heroics-in-special-jimmys-winning-matches-documentary/|title=RTÉ to show Donegal's All-Ireland heroics in special 'Jimmy's Winning Matches' documentary|work=Donegal Daily|date=2 January 2013|accessdate=2 January 2013}} The documentary featured an exclusive interview with McGuinness filmed at his [[Glenties]] home, while Rory Gallagher, who penned the famous song, also featured, with Alan Foley doing the research.{{cite news|url=http://www.donegaldemocrat.ie/sport/local-sport/donegal-s-all-ireland-win-to-feature-on-rte-documentary-1-4635273|title=Donegal's All-Ireland win to feature on RTÉ documentary|newspaper=Donegal Democrat|date=2 January 2013|accessdate=2 January 2013}} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Donegal GAA}} [[Category:2012 in Gaelic football]] [[Category:2013 in Irish television]] [[Category:All-Ireland Senior Football Championship]] [[Category:Documentary films about sportspeople]] [[Category:Documentary television films]] [[Category:Donegal GAA]] [[Category:Gaelic games culture]] [[Category:Irish documentary films]] [[Category:Irish films]] [[Category:Sports television in Ireland]] {{sport-documentary-stub}}

A '''kick''' in a running race is the ability of some athletes to [[Sprint running|sprint]] at the end of an endurance oriented race.<ref>https://www.hillrunner.com/jim2/id205.html</ref> For those who possess the ability to kick, it is a strategic weapon. For those with the liability not to possess a kick, they must seek [[Pacing strategies in track and field|different strategies]] to anticipate and diminish their opponent's kicking power, usually by a long extended surge to break away or exhaust their opponent well ahead of the finish of the race. Similar to a [[Sprinter (cycling)|Sprinter]] in cycling, a kicker has a finite distance they know they are able to sprint, making their strategy to be in the ideal position at that distance to be able to utilize that speed. Sprinting too early could lead an athlete to tie up, a form of [[rigor mortis]] before reaching the finish line. Thus team tactics might also intentionally or not, box a kicker, meaning to position other competitors to their outside, to disrupt their positioning and timing. Of course, as the finish is nearing and all athletes are straining, this becomes more difficult to accomplish deliberately.
In modern history, most championship races turn strategic. Very rarely will an athlete risk going out on their own to attempt to [[Breakaway (cycling)|breakaway]], therefore leaving the race result to the best timed kick. While the drafting effects of pack running are not as accentuated as they are in a cycling [[Peloton]], the psychological teamwork of a unified group rarely rewards the breakaway athlete. Some notable exceptions include [[Almaz Ayana]], who not known for her sprint speed, broke away to take [[Athletics at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Women's 10,000 metres|2016 Olympic 10,000 metres]] in world record time. A week later, the same [[Vivian Cheruiyot]] she had vanquished in the 10,000m, did not let her breakaway in the [[Athletics at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Women's 5000 metres|5000]]. [[Ruth Jebet]] also burned off her opponent's kick in the [[Athletics at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Women's 3000 metres steeplechase|steeplechase]].
In the [[800 metres]], some athletes develop the reputation for being a kicker because of their apparent speed at the end of the race, when in reality the ran even splits. Most of that speed is relative to the exhaustion as their opponents slow. [[Dave Wottle]], [[James Robinson (runner)|James Robinson]], [[Yuriy Borzakovskiy]], [[Nick Symmonds]] and [[Amel Tuka]] would take the beginning of the race out slowly, re-gaining contact with the rest of the field near the last 200 metres. At the elite men's level, that even pace would be about 26 seconds per 200 meters; a 52 second first lap, as compared with the leaders close to or under 50 seconds. World record holder [[David Rudisha]] burned off the kickers during his world record [[Athletics at the 2012 Summer Olympics – Men's 800 metres|2012 Gold medal]]. When he won the [[2015 World Championships in Athletics – Men's 800 metres|2015 World Championships]], he blew away even paced kickers like Tuka with a remarkably fast final 24.34 200 metre true kick of his own.
Generally most long kickers or extended kickers would accelerate in the penultimate lap or shortly after the bell indicating the last lap has begun. A speed kicker would behave more like an anchor runner in a 4x400 relay, positioning themselves on the shoulder of their opponent and using their burst of speed as late as the final straightaway.
[[Mo Farah]] developed a reputation as a strategic runner. His finishing kick was not so much a burst of speed, but his extended ability to repeatedly accelerate just enough to discourage anybody from passing him during an intense final lap or so of his races. His [[Nike Oregon Project]] teammate [[Matthew Centrowitz Jr.]] employed a similar form of holding the lead to win his [[Athletics at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Men's 1500 metres|2016 gold medal in the 1500]].
Because of the advantage of having the tool of a kick in a competitor's arsenal, the techniques to train to kick are a common discussion among runners and coaches.<ref>https://www.verywellfit.com/how-to-finish-strong-in-running-races-2910928</ref><ref>http://www.letsrun.com/forum/flat_read.php?thread=5048842</ref><ref>https://running.competitor.com/2014/10/training/ask-mario-improve-kick_115237</ref><ref>https://www.realbuzz.com/articles-interests/running/article/how-to-perfect-the-finishing-kick-or-sprint-finish-in-a-race/</ref><ref>http://runners-resource.com/how-to-develop-a-kick/</ref><ref>https://www.runnersworld.com/advanced/a20799128/a-lethal-kick/</ref>
==Notable kickers== * [[Fermín Cacho]] * [[Sebastian Coe]] * [[Eamonn Coghlan]] * [[Alberto Cova]] * [[Haile Gebrselassie]] * [[Shelby Houlihan]] * [[Ezekiel Kemboi]] * [[Bernard Lagat]] * [[Douglas Lowe (athlete)|Douglas Lowe]] * [[Billy Mills]] * [[Steve Ovett]] * [[Jim Ryun]] * [[Peter Snell]] * [[Miruts Yifter]]
==Extended kickers== * [[Matthew Centrowitz Jr.]] * [[Steve Cram]] * [[Hicham El Guerrouj]] * [[Mo Farah]] * [[Lasse Virén]]

[[Malta]] | coordinates = {{coord|35|50|11.2|N|14|32|36.4|E|display=it}} | broke_ground = | built = | opened = | renovated = | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Marsaxlokk F.C.|Marsaxlokk]] | operator = Marsaxlokk | surface = Grass | construction_cost = | architect = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | project_manager = | main_contractors = | former_names = | tenants = [[Marsaxlokk F.C.|Marsaxlokk]] | capacity = 1,000 | dimensions = | scoreboard = }} '''Marsaxlokk Ground''' is a [[association football|football]] pitch in [[Marsaxlokk]], a traditional [[fishing village]] located in the south-eastern part of [[Malta]]. The ground is used mostly for football matches and is the home stadium of [[Marsaxlokk F.C.|Marsaxlokk Football Club]]. [[Marsaxlokk FC]] uses this ground for training and practice matches. [[Marsaxlokk F.C.|Marsaxlokk]] would play their European games at the ground, but the club play their league matches at the [[Ta' Qali National Stadium]], since most of the [[Maltese Premier League]] matches are played there, and also because the ground has a very low capacity. ==External links== {{Marsaxlokk F.C.}} [[Category:Football venues in Malta]] [[Category:Marsaxlokk]] [[Category:Marsaxlokk F.C.]] {{Malta-sports-venue-stub}}

revision.text:
'''Mike Beacom''' is a professional and [[college football]] writer, and the president and chairman of the [[Fantasy Sports Writers Association]] (FSWA).
== Pro and college football writer == Beacom writes a regular retro column for Pro Football Weekly and has contributed to [[Sports Illustrated|SI.com]]’s fantasy football section since 2006. He has also covered [[Big Ten Conference|Big Ten]] football for a number of national outlets, including Lindy’s, Athlon and CSTV (now [[CBS Sports Network|CBS Sports]]).
== Football history == Much of Beacom’s work has been focused on historical themes. In 2006, Beacom researched all of the past [[Super Bowl Most Valuable Player Award|Super Bowl MVP]] winners and offered alternative choices for each game based on insight he received from leading NFL experts. The article was recognized as one of the year’s best articles by the [[Pro Football Writers Association|Pro Football Writers of America]]. Two years later Beacom wrote a piece for SI.com picking the winners of the Heisman races from 1900 to 1934 (the 35 years before the trophy was established) based on research he had conducted.
== Fantasy Sports Writers Association (FSWA) == Beacom was asked to serve as the group’s chairman when it was created in 2004. On January 1, 2008, he assumed the duties of president, and during his term he has helped to launch the FSWA Hall of Fame, which recognizes those writers, editors and publishers who have made a lasting impact on the fantasy sports industry. Wrote ESPN’s Matthew Berry in 2010 of the honor, “Very humbling for me. Thrilled, honored, touched and many other emotions raced through me.”<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.espn.com/fantasy/football/ffl/story?page=tmr100914|title=The Talented Mr. Roto: Week 2 pickups|date=2010-09-15|website=ESPN.com|access-date=2017-04-06}}</ref>
== Author == Beacom has penned several books, including “The Complete Idiot's Guide to Understanding Football,” which was released by [[Alpha Books]] in 2010.
== Personal == Beacom resides with his family in [[central Wisconsin]] where he serves as an associate lecturer of journalism at a nearby university. He is a graduate of the [[University of Wisconsin–Stevens Point]] where he was a Communication major and awards an annual scholarship to students who excel in internships or employment.
== Awards and recognition == • Author of the Best Wisconsin Sports Story of 2009, Milwaukee Press Club<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://milwaukeepressclub.org/2009-excellence-in-journalism-awardees/|title=2009 Excellence in Journalism Awardees {{!}} Milwaukee Press Club|website=milwaukeepressclub.org|language=en-US|access-date=2017-04-06}}</ref>
• Runner-up, Best Wisconsin Sports Story of 2010, Milwaukee Press Club<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://milwaukeepressclub.org/2010-excellence-in-journalism-awardees/|title=2010 Excellence in Journalism Awardees {{!}} Milwaukee Press Club|website=milwaukeepressclub.org|language=en-US|access-date=2017-04-06}}</ref>
• Runner-up, Best Enterprise Feature, Pro Football Writers of America
== External links == * [http://www.mikebeacom.com/ Mike Beacom official website] *[[Fantasy Sports Writers Association|Fantasy Sports Writers of America (FSWA)]] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20110512055323/http://www.profootballweekly.com/staff/mike-beacom/ Beacom’s Pro Football Weekly columns] *[[Milwaukee Press Club]] *[[Pro Football Writers Association|Pro Football Writers of America]] * [[Fantasy sports|Fantasy Sports]]

The [[combat sport]] of [[Muay Thai]] has been featured in media, including film, television, manga, anime and video games. It gained international attention when [[Yodtong Senanan]] led the Nak Muay Team against Osamu Noguchi's Kickboxer Team on October 16, 1972.{{cite web |url = http://www.defcross.be/Defcross/Muay%20Thai.htm |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20070710005048/http://www.defcross.be/Defcross/Muay%20Thai.htm |dead-url = yes |archive-date = 2007-07-10 |title = Muay Thai |last = Hion |first = Jeffrey |accessdate = 2012-11-07 |work = Defcross.be |df = }} It has heavily influenced the sport of [[kickboxing]], and is used in [[mixed martial arts]] (MMA), where athletes train in its techniques. ==Film== {{refimprove section|date=November 2012|1=please provide references for descriptions of movie to include Muay Thai}} Muay Thai has been featured in an assortment of films: {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Movie ! Year ! Description |- | ''Master KIMs'' | – | The Nak Muay team appears in the final scene.{{citation needed|date=November 2012}} |- | ''[[Duel of Fists]]'' | 1971 | A [[Hong Kong]] engineer ([[David Chiang]]) goes to [[Thailand]] to find his long-lost half-brother ([[Ti Lung]]), who is a [[Muay Thai]] boxer. |- |- | ''[[Bloodsport (film)|Bloodsport]]'' | 1988 | Paco (Paulo Tocha) is a Muay Thai practitioner. |- | ''[[A Fighter's Blues]]''
(A Fu) | 2000 | Mong Fu ([[Andy Lau]]), a former Muay Thai boxer, returns to Thailand from Hong Kong and challenges the champion to a match. |- | ''[[Beautiful Boxer]]'' | 2003 | The life story of [[Parinya Charoenphol]] (Asanee Suwan), who masters Muay Thai in order to realize her dream of becoming a woman. |- | ''[[Ong-Bak: Muay Thai Warrior]]'' | 2003 | The series popularized Muay Thai, and featured some [[Muay Boran]] techniques. The film had two sequels: ''[[Ong Bak 2]]'' (2008) and ''[[Ong Bak 3]]'' (2010) |- | ''[[Born to Fight (2004 film)|Born to Fight]]'' | 2004 | [[Dan Chupong]] stars in the film.{{fact|date=November 2012|reason=does the film feature Muay Thai in it or does it only have a Muay Thai actor?}} |- | ''Chok-Dee: The Kickboxer'' | 2005 | The film is based on the life of [[Algeria]]n-[[France|French]] Muay Thai boxer [[Dida Diafat]], who stars as himself.{{cite web | url=http://www.muaythaitv.com/pages/news/news.php?s_id=551 | title=Diafat Bio | publisher=muaythaitv.com | accessdate=2006-03-01}} |- | ''[[Tom-Yum-Goong]]'' | 2005 | [[Tony Jaa]], who starred in the movie and was also the fight choreographer, incorporates a Muay Thai style (มวยคชสาร, "muaykodchasarn", roughly translated as "Elephant Boxing"), which emphasizes grappling moves. The movie also showcased "Jaturongkabaht", which was used by the Royal Thai Bodyguards.{{citation needed|date=November 2012|reason=is Jaturongkabaht a Muay Thai style?}} |- | ''[[Fight or Flight (film)|Fight or Flight]]'' | 2007 | A documentary on Thailand's ring fighting circuit. |- | ''[[Muay Thai Chaiya]]'' | 2007 | Is a film about two talented muay Thai boxers, boyhood friends whose lives take divergent paths after they arrive in Bangkok. |- | ''[[Chocolate (2008 film)|Chocolate]]'' | 2008 | Muay Thai fighters [[Yanin Vismitananda]] and [[Lim Su-Jeong (kickboxer)|Lim Su-Jeong]] star in this film.{{fact|date=November 2012|reason=does this movie feature Muay Thai or does it only have Muay Thai actors?}} |- | ''Down for the Count''
(Aukmen) | 2009 | Muay Thai boxer Ahmad Al-Sulaiti appears as himself. |- | ''[[The Kick (film)|The Kick]]'' | 2011 | A Korean family of [[Taekwondo]] experts immigrate to [[Thailand]] and are exposed to Muay Thai fighting.{{cite web|url=http://www.thaicinema.org/kits288thekick.asp |title=ÇÍ¹â´¹àµÐ |publisher=Thaicinema.org |date= |accessdate=2012-11-08}} |- | ''[[Only God Forgives]]'' | 2013 | A Bangkok policeman and a gangster settle their differences in a Muay Thai match. |- | ''[[A Prayer Before Dawn (film)|A Prayer Before Dawn]]'' | 2017 | The film is based on the true life experience of Billy Moore who survived his Thai prison ordeal by becoming a Muay Thai boxing champion. |} ==Television== Muay Thai has been featured in television series from [[reality show]] contests to documentary episodes. {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Television Show ! Episode ! Description |- | ''[[The Contender Asia]]'' | series | A [[Reality television|reality-based]] [[television series]] that follows 16 aspiring Muay Thai middleweight fighters from 12 countries as they compete in a series of outdoor challenges and sanctioned matches.{{cite news| title=''The Contender Asia'' kicks off| date=September 9, 2007| publisher=OnScreenAsia.com| url=http://www.onscreenasia.com/article-843-thecontenderasiakicksoff-onscreenasia.html| accessdate=2008-01-16| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080117152458/http://www.onscreenasia.com/article-843-thecontenderasiakicksoff-onscreenasia.html| archivedate=January 17, 2008| df=}} |- | ''[[Human Weapon]]'' | [[Human Weapon#Episodes and airdates|"Muay Thai"]] | The episode featured the history and fighting techniques of Muay Thai. |- | ''[[True Life]]'' | [[True Life#Season 5 (2004)|"I'm a Muay Thai Fighter"]] | [[Kit Cope]] and Ben Garcia travel overseas to make their mark in the brutal world of Muay Thai ring fighting. They are scheduled to compete in bare-knuckle fights that will be broadcast on Thailand television. |- | ''[[Fight Girls]]'' | series | A reality show similar to ''[[The Ultimate Fighter]]'', where ten female fighters live together and train with a Muay Thai instructor in [[Las Vegas Valley|Las Vegas]] for six weeks in an effort to fight for a Muay Thai championship in Thailand. |- | ''[[Fight Quest]]'' | [[Fight Quest#Season 2|"Thailand"]] | Jimmy Smith and Doug Anderson learn Muay Thai. |- | ''[[Dhani Tackles the Globe]]'' | [[Dhani Tackles the Globe#Episodes - Season One|"Thailand"]] | [[Dhani Jones]] learns Muay Thai. |- | ''[[Babylon 5]]'' | [[TKO (Babylon 5)|"TKO"]] | [[Michael Garibaldi]] and his friend Walker Smith participate in an alien-run tournament called the "Mutai". |- | ''[[Gaki no Tsukai]]'' | – | The variety show features a "Thai Kick" punishment game where a boxer delivers a kick to the loser's backside. |- | ''[[The Challenge (TV series)|Real World/Road Rules Challenge]]'' | [[Real World/Road Rules Challenge: The Ruins|"The Ruins"]] | featured a "Muay Thai challenge" where contestants kicked bamboo sticks in an elimination round. |- | ''[[Ring Girls]]'' | series | A reality show similar to ''[[The Ultimate Fighter]]'', where ten female fighters live together and train with a Muay Thai instructor in [[Las Vegas Valley|Las Vegas]] for six weeks in an effort to fight for a Muay Thai championship in Thailand. |- | ''[[Power Rangers]]/[[Juken Sentai Gekiranger]]'' | [[Power Rangers Jungle Fury]] season | [[Jungle Fury Power Rangers#Robert "R.J." James|Robert "R.J." James]], the Jungle Fury Wolf Ranger who wears violet, is a Muay Thai practitioner. He wears ''prajed'' (dual elbow bands) uses elbow and knee attacks, including a flying knee strike. |- | ''[[An Idiot Abroad]]'' | [[List of An Idiot Abroad episodes#ep11|"Swim With Dolphins"]] | [[Karl Pilkington]] trains with a Muay Thai kickboxing group and later participates in a blindfolded match.{{cite web|url=http://sky1.sky.com/an-idiot-abroad/an-idiot-abroad-2-swim-with-dolphins |title=An Idiot Abroad 2 Episode 3: Swim With Dolphins – Sky1 HD |publisher=Sky1.sky.com |date= |accessdate=2011-10-07}} |} ==Manga and Animation== Manga and anime shows occasionally feature characters who use Muay Thai techniques. Soman Sono Arikton and [[Tadashi Sawamura]] from the 1970 show {{Nihongo3|''The Kick Demon''|キックの鬼|Kick no Oni}} are among the first Muay Thai characters to appear in anime.{{citation needed|date=November 2012|reason=need information on this}} The list includes appearances from other animations. {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Manga or Animation ! Character(s) |- | ''[[Tatakae!! Ramenman]]'' | Muay Thai Chūchai |- | ''[[Dragon Ball]]'' | Draculaman, Pamput |- | ''Shingeki no Kyojin'' | Female titan |- | ''Noritaka'' | Sawamura Noritaka, Tchan-Poua |- | ''[[List of Captain Tsubasa World Youth chapters|Captain Tsubasa World Youth]]'' | Bunnaak Singprasert |- | ''Karate Shokoshi Kohinata Minoru''{{cite web | url = http://www.ten-ryu.org/article-karate-shoukoushi-kohinata-minoru-51728242.html | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20100706104244/http://www.ten-ryu.org/article-karate-shoukoushi-kohinata-minoru-51728242.html | archivedate = 2010-07-06 | date = 2009-02-25 | deadurl = yes | title = 空手小公子 小日向海流 – Karate Shoukoushi Kohinata Minoru | work = Ten Ryû, culture japonaise et arts-martiaux | accessdate = 2012-11-07 | language = French }} | Samart Sarindu, Charndech Nham Sae Gym

{{Infobox sports award | name= [[File:Olympic rings without rims.svg|40px]] Olympic Order | image= {{double image|right||150| |135|Gold Olympic Order|Silver Olympic Order|Gold Olympic Order|Silver Olympic Order}} | image_size= | caption= Gold and Silver Olympic Orders | givenfor= Contribution to the [[Olympic Movement]] | presenter= [[File:Olympic rings without rims.svg|30px]] [[International Olympic Committee]] | first= 1975 | number= | last= | mostwins= [[Nadia Comăneci]] {{flagicon|ROU}} (2 times i.e. 1984, 2004) | mostrecent= }}
[[File:Ordine Olimpico.jpg|thumb|Olympic Order and its relative badge, produced by [[GDE Bertoni|GDE Bertoni Milano]], Collection Fabio Ferrari]] The '''Olympic Order''' is the highest award of the Olympic Movement and is awarded for particularly distinguished contributions to the Olympic Movement, i.e. recognition of efforts worthy of merit in the cause of sport. It was established in May 1975 by the [[International Olympic Committee]] as a successor to the ''Olympic Certificate''. The Olympic Order originally had three grades ([[Gold medal|gold]], [[Silver medal|silver]] and [[Bronze medal|bronze]]). In 1984, at the 87th IOC Session in [[Sarajevo]] ([[Yugoslavia]]), it was decided that in future there would be no distinction between the silver and bronze order. The gold order would continue to be awarded in exceptional circumstances. Traditionally, the [[IOC]] bestows the Olympic Order upon the chief national organiser(s) at the closing ceremony of each respective [[Olympic Games]].
The insignia of the Olympic Order is in the form of a ''collar'' (or [[chain]]), in Gold, Silver or Bronze according to grade; the front of the chain depicts the five rings of the [[Olympic Movement]], flanked on either side by ''kotinos'' emblem ([[olive wreath]]). A lapel badge, in the form of the five rings in Gold, Silver and Bronze according to grade, is presented to recipients to wear as appropriate.
[[Nadia Comăneci]] is the only athlete to be awarded the Olympic Order twice (1984, 2004). She is also the youngest recipient of Olympic Order since 1984 when she was only 23 years old at the time of award.

revision.text:
The '''Parramatta Eels salary cap breach''' was a major breach of the [[National Rugby League]]'s strictly enforced [[salary cap]] by the [[Parramatta Eels]] rugby league club over a period of four years. The discovery of these breaches in 2016 by the NRL resulted in it stripping the Eels of the twelve competition points the club has accrued so far in the [[2016 NRL season]]. In addition to being fined $1 million, Parramatta also had its [[2016 NRL Auckland Nines]] title revoked.<ref name="salary-cap-1">{{cite web|url=http://www.nrl.com/eels-breaches-must-stop-today-greenberg/tabid/10874/newsid/95541/default.aspx|title=Eels breaches must stop today: Greenberg|publisher=NRL.com|first=Martin|last=Gabor|date=3 May 2016|accessdate=3 May 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nrl.com/greenberg-addressed-shattered-eels-players/tabid/10874/newsid/95548/default.aspx|title=Greenberg addressed 'shattered' Eels players|publisher=NRL.com|first=Martin|last=Gabor|date=3 May 2016|accessdate=3 May 2016}}</ref>
==The investigation== Prior to the start of the 2016 NRL season, the [[Parramatta Eels]] faced the prospect with starting the season on -4 points due to salary cap indiscretions in 2015, however the NRL was satisfied with governance changes at the Eels and no points were deducted.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.theage.com.au/rugby-league/parramatta-eels/parramatta-eels-avoid-fourpoint-nrl-penalty-over-governance-issues-20160302-gn8m48.html | title=Parramatta Eels avoid four-point NRL penalty over governance issues | publisher=theage.com.au | date=2 March 2016 | accessdate=3 March 2016}}</ref>
However, it was revealed in March that third-party payments had been made by several companies to several players, which is strictly prohibited in the NRL.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2016-05-03/eels-salary-cap-investigation-findings-set-to-be-handed-down/7378204?section=sport|title=Parramatta Eels salary cap investigation findings to be handed down by the NRL|publisher=ABC News ([[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]])|date=3 May 2016|accessdate=3 May 2016}}</ref>
On 3 May 2016, NRL CEO Todd Greenberg announced that the club would be docked the twelve competition points they have accrued so far this season, as well as fined $1 million and stripped of the [[2016 NRL Auckland Nines]] title it won in February.<ref name="salary-cap-1"/> In addition, the NRL also announced that the Eels would not be able to accrue any further competition points until they fall under the salary cap, which they were reported to be $500,000 over as of 3 May 2016.<ref name="Brunsdon">{{cite web|url=http://www.foxsports.com.au/nrl/nrl-premiership/parramatta-eels-players-will-not-be-forced-out-amid-cap-drama-promises-rlpa/news-story/68acdc2430cbadea91dcfdff230d238d|title=Parramatta Eels players will not be forced out amid cap drama, promises RLPA|publisher=Fox Sports Australia|first=Simon|last=Brunsdon|date=3 May 2016|accessdate=3 May 2016}}</ref> Five officials, including chairman Steve Sharp, deputy chairman Tom Issa, director Peter Serrao, chief executive John Boulous and football manager Daniel Anderson, were also sacked.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2016-05-03/parramatta-eels-docked-12-nrl-points-salary-cap-breach/7377704|title=Parramatta Eels docked 12 competition points by the NRL for salary cap breaches|publisher=ABC News ([[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]])|date=3 May 2016|accessdate=3 May 2016}}</ref>
On 9 July, after over 2 months of club officials contesting the preliminary penalties, Parramatta were handed their punishment with the addition of their for/against points tally accumulated from rounds 1-9 being deducted.<ref>{{cite news|title=Parramatta final determination|url=http://www.nrl.com/parramatta-final-determination/tabid/10874/newsid/98979/default.aspx|website=NRL.com|date=9 July 2016}}</ref>
The main point of interest in this episode was the manner of the punishment when compared to the [[Melbourne Storm salary cap breach]] in 2010, while the Melbourne Storm were not allowed to play for points for the whole season the Parramatta Eels were permitted to play for points as soon as they fell back in line with the cap.<ref name="Brunsdon"/> It was acknowledged that this change was made due to the demoralising nature of the Storm punishment and having to witness a team running out week after week with nothing to play for.
==Suspects==
{{Empty section|date=September 2018}}
==Reaction==
The aftermath ended with Parramatta hooker Nathan Peats being squeezed out of the club, so the club would be just under the salary cap and start playing for competition points for the remainder of the season. Though this did very little for the troubled club finishing the NRL season 13th on the ladder winning only six of their last 14 matches.
==See also== {{Portal|Sydney|Rugby league}} *[[Carlton Football Club salary cap breach]] *[[Melbourne Storm salary cap breach]]
==References== {{reflist}}

Benfica]] | tenants = [[S.L. Benfica (handball)|Handball]]
[[S.L. Benfica (volleyball)|Volleyball]] | website = [http://www.slbenfica.pt/en-us/estadio/pavilhoes/pavilhaonumerodois.aspx slbenfica.pt] | publictransit = Alto dos Moinhos and Colégio Militar/Luz
[[Lisbon Metro]] Blue Line }} The '''Pavilhão da Luz Nº 2''' is the second [[indoor arena|arena]] of Portuguese multi-sport club [[S.L. Benfica]]. It has a capacity of 1,800 seats and it is mainly used by the [[S.L. Benfica (handball)|handball]] and [[S.L. Benfica (volleyball)|volleyball]] departments of the club. Its construction ran at the same time as the adjacent arena, [[Pavilhão da Luz Nº 1]], but it was finished just a couple weeks later.{{cite news|title=A catedral das modalidades|trans-title=The cathedral of sports|url=http://www.record.xl.pt/futebol/futebol-nacional/liga-nos/benfica/detalhe/a-catedral-das-modalidades.html|accessdate=21 March 2016|work=Record|date=28 February 2004|language=Portuguese}} Because the old Pavilhão da Luz was at full capacity with five sports, Benfica planned the new [[Estádio da Luz]] with two indoor arenas; the smaller one only hosting two departments.{{cite news|title=Seara Cardoso abre «caixinha» da nova Luz|trans-title=Seara Cardoso opens "little box" of the new Luz|url=http://www.record.xl.pt/futebol/futebol-nacional/liga-nos/benfica/detalhe/seara-cardoso-abre-caixinha-da-nova-luz.html|accessdate=21 March 2016|work=Record.pt|date=4 December 2002|language=Portuguese}} Its differences from the main arena are its roof and its two side stands, who sit fewer people. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{Official website}} {{pt icon}} {{S.L. Benfica}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Pavilhao da Luz N 2}} [[Category:S.L. Benfica]] [[Category:Indoor arenas in Portugal]] [[Category:Sports venues in Lisbon]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2004]] [[Category:Handball venues]] [[Category:Volleyball venues in Portugal]] {{portugal-sports-venue-stub}}

2015 (stadium) | renovated = | expanded = | closed = | demolished = 2017 (stadium) | owner = | operator = Ramblewood Soccer, Inc. | surface = Grass | scoreboard = | cost = | architect = | project_manager = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | main_contractors = | capacity = 4,700 | suites = | record_attendance = | dimensions = 120 x 75 yards | acreage = | tenants = [[Charlotte Independence]] ([[United Soccer League|USL]]) (2015–2017) }} '''Ramblewood Soccer Complex''' is a volunteer maintained sports complex consisting of eleven soccer fields, located in [[Charlotte, North Carolina]]. The complex features a 4,300-seat [[soccer-specific stadium]], which had been home to the [[Charlotte Independence]] soccer club since 2015. The stadium was built beginning in 2014, although the complex as a whole dates back to 1993. ==External links== * [http://www.ramblewoodsoccer.org/ Ramblewood Soccer Complex] * [http://www.charlotteindependence.com/ Charlotte Independence] [[Category:Charlotte Independence]] [[Category:Soccer venues in North Carolina]] [[Category:1993 establishments in North Carolina]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1993]] {{NorthCarolina-sports-venue-stub}}

{{Unreferenced|date=November 2014}} {{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Estadio Romelio Martínez | nickname = | image = EstadioRomelioMatrinez.jpg | image_size = 200px | fullname = Plaza de eventos del estadio Romelio Martínez | location = [[Barranquilla]], [[Colombia]] | coordinates = {{coord|10|59|38|N|74|48|25|W|display=it|type:landmark}} | broke_ground = | built = | opened = 1934 | renovated = | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = | operator = | surface = | construction_cost = US$120,000 | architect = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor= | project_manager = | main_contractors = | former_names = | tenants = [[Barranquilla F.C.]]
[[Junior F.C.]] (formerly) | seating_capacity = 20,000 | dimensions = }} The '''Estadio Romelio Martínez''', or '''Romelio Martínez Stadium''', is a sports stadium located at 72 street and 46 Avenue in the [[Colombia]]n city of [[Barranquilla]]. It has a capacity of 20,000 spectators. Until the construction of the [[Estadio Metropolitano Roberto Meléndez]] in 1986, the Romelio Martínez had been the city's primary stadium. It is currently the home of the [[Barranquilla F.C.]] soccer team, which plays in the [[Categoría Primera B|Colombian second division]]. == History == The project was conceived on 1932, because that year the [[National Games of Colombia]] were to be made in Barranquilla and was built in the ground that occupied the "Estadio Juana de Arco". The stadium was finished on 1934 with the name of "Estadio Municipal" (Municipal Stadium). The initial capacity of the stadium was of 10,000 spectators. Has a wooden structure that support the deck of the grandstand and the architectural stadium's style is [[Art Deco]]. The Romelio Martínez Stadium hosted the [[1946 Central American and Caribbean Games|V Central American and Caribbean Games]] in 1946. Since the born of the [[Categoría Primera A|professional football]] in Barranquilla on 1948, had the need of enlarge the capacity of the stadium because sometimes many fans of the [[Junior de Barranquilla|local team]] of the city exceeded the total capacity, forcing to make long lines in the entry since the first hours of the day. == References == {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Estadio Romelio Martinez}} [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1934|Romelio Martinez]] [[Category:Football venues in Colombia|Romelio Martinez]] [[Category:1934 establishments in Colombia]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Barranquilla]] [[Category:National Monuments of Colombia]] {{Colombia-sports-venue-stub}}

The '''Royal Dutch Cycling Union''' or '''KNWU''' (in [[Dutch language|Dutch]]: ''Koninklijke Nederlandsche Wielren Unie'') is the national [[sport governing body|governing body]] of [[bicycle racing|cycle racing]] in the [[Netherlands]].
The aim of the KNWU is to give adequate support for all types of cycling in sports loving Netherlands.
The KNWU is a member of the [[Union Cycliste Internationale|UCI]] and the [[Union Européenne de Cyclisme|UEC]].
==Events organized by the KNWU== *Dutch Cycling Championships **[[Dutch National Road Race Championships]] **[[Dutch National Time Trial Championships]] **[[Dutch National Track Championships]] *[[UCI Road World Championships]] for professionals in [[1938 UCI Road World Championships|1938]], [[1948 UCI Road World Championships|1948]], [[1959 UCI Road World Championships|1959]], [[1967 UCI Road World Championships|1967]], [[1979 UCI Road World Championships|1979]], [[1998 UCI Road World Championships|1998]] and [[2012 UCI Road World Championships|2012]] *[[UCI Track World Championships]] for professionals in [[1938 UCI Track World Championships|1938]], [[1948 UCI Track World Championships|1948]], [[1959 UCI Track World Championships|1959]], [[1967 UCI Road World Championships|1967]], [[1979 UCI Road World Championships|1979]] and [[2011 UCI Road World Championships|2011]]
==External links== * [http://www.knwu.nl/ Royal Dutch Cycling Union official website]

revision.text:
{{Expert-subject|Martial arts|date=February 2009}} [[File:Лубок.jpg|thumb|right|260px|A [[lubok]] depiction of the "Wall on Wall" (''Stenka na Stenku'') fist fighting.]] {{Russian martial arts}} '''Russian boxing''' ([[Russian language|Russian]] - Кулачный бой ''Kulachniy Boy'' "fist fighting, pugilism") is the traditional [[bare-knuckle boxing]] of [[Russia]].
==History== The earliest accounts concerning the sport date to the 13th century.<ref>''Russian Fist Fighting''. "Летописцы наши говорят об ней, еще в начале XIII в. [Our sources talked about it already at the 13th century.]"</ref> Supposedly,{{By whom|date=June 2011}} fist fighting was practiced even prior to the [[Christianization of Kievan Rus']], at celebrations dedicated to [[Perun]].{{Dubious|date=June 2011}}<ref name="Севостьянов В.М., Бурцев Г.А., Пшеницын А.В.">{{cite book|last=Sevostyanov |first=V. М. |last2=Burtsev |first2=G. А. |last3=Pshenitsyn |first3=А. V. |title=Рукопашный бой |trans-title=Russian Pugilism| location=Moscow| publisher=Data Strom |year= 1991 | ISBN= 5-7130-0003-6 | page =190}} </ref>
Metropolite Kiril, in 1274, created another one of many personally-instituted rules, declaring expulsion from Christianity for any of those who fist-fight and do not sing a prayer or hymn at the burial of someone who died during a fist fight.{{Verify credibility|date=June 2011}}<ref name="Русская цивилизация">{{cite web|author= |last= |first= |authorlink= |coauthors= |date= |url=http://www.rustrana.ru/article.php?nid=3006 |title=The Russian Civilization |trans-title=|format= |work=К истории кулачных боёв |publisher= |accessdate=28 August 2008 |description= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070519055902/http://www.rustrana.ru/article.php?nid=3006 |archivedate=May 19, 2007 }}</ref> The government itself never supported, but also never opposed fist fighting.<ref name="Русская цивилизация" />
Russian [[boyar]]s used the sport as mass entertainment, and acquired the best fighters for competitions.<ref>Sakharov, Ivan P., ''Сказания русского народа'', p. 129. "Было время, когда русские бояре, собравшись повеселиться, свозили из разных городов бойцов для потешения. [There was a time when Russian boyars when came together to have fun, brought from different cities fighters for fun.]"</ref>
The fights most often took place in holiday times and in crowded places. In winter it took place on ice. First the young children fought, then every pair was more grown up than the previous, ending with the last and most notable fist fighters.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.infosport.ru/Press/SZR/0798/topic1.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-08-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080822012307/http://www.infosport.ru/Press/SZR/0798/topic1.htm |archivedate=2008-08-22 |df= }} "лишь постепенно вводились в дело все более сильные отряды. Первыми выходили ребятишки, затем подростки, юноши, неженатые парни, а уж затем - взрослые мужчины. [Only after a while the strongest ones were brought. The first were the kids, then teens, then lads, and only then grown up men.] {{cite web |url=http://www.infosport.ru/Press/SZR/0798/topic1.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-08-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080117155052/http://www.infosport.ru/Press/SZR/0798/topic1.htm |archivedate=January 17, 2008 |df= }}</ref><ref>Labzyuk, Sergei, "Историческая справка: кулачный бой". "Бои происходили обыкновенно в праздничные дни и при жилых местах, а зимой чаще всего на льду. Сначала пускали вперед как бы застрельщиков, мальчишек. За ними мало-по-малу группировались более взрослые, но главная партия противников оставалась в резерве, особенно известные по своей силе и искусству бойцы. [The fights usually took place at holidays and in rural areas, and in winter most often on ice. First the boys were let in, and then more and more grown ups. The best fighters were kept for the end.]"</ref>
In two orders released in 1684 and 1686 fist fighting was forbidden, but the sport continued to live.<ref>{{cite book|first = Robert Nisbet| last = Bain|title = The Pupils of Peter the Great: A History of the Russian Court and Empire from 1697 to 1740|publisher = A. Constable and Co.|year = 1897|location=Westminster|page = 89|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=7NQKAAAAIAAJ|isbn = 978-0-548-05007-1 |quote=...Thus a Ukaz was issued to put a stop to the brutality of the Kulachny boi, or fist-fight. This popular game was not abolished, but those who chose to amuse themselves thereby, were to do so, in future, under police supervision ... }}</ref><ref>''Russian Fist Fighting''. "Указами 1684 года ноября 2, 1686 года марта 19 и другими, строго воспрещались кулачные бои... Было время, что старики, воспламеняя умы молодых людей, несбыточными рассказами об удальстве бойцов, пробуждали в них страсть к кулачному бою." (With orders released in 1684, and 1686, Fist fights were forbidden... The old people, with their stories about the sport encouraged the young people to continue with it)</ref>
All regions had their heroes at the sport, but the region with the most famous ones historically is [[Tula, Russia|Tula]].<ref>''Russian Fist Fighting''. "Тульские бойцы и ныне славятся, но каждое место имело своих удальцов." (Tulas fighters were always glorious, but every place had its heroes)</ref><ref>Sakharov, Ivan P., ''Сказания русского народа'', p. 129. "Лучшими бойцами один на один считались тульские [The best fighters in one-on-one were considered Tula's fighters.]"</ref>
There are documents saying [[Peter the Great]] liked to organize fist fights "in order to show the ability of the [[Russians|Russian people]]".<ref name="Интернет-портал «Легендарный Физтех», «Физтех-центр»">{{cite web | author = | last =Romanenko | first =M. I. | authorlink = | coauthors = | date = | url = http://boxing.fizteh.ru/papers/romanenko/glava01.html?xsl:print=1 | script-title=ru:Интернет-портал "Легендарный Физтех", "Физтех-центр" | format = | work = <nowiki>Краткий исторический обзор развития бокса как вида спорта [A brief historical overview of the development of boxing as a sport]</nowiki> | publisher = | accessdate = 1 August 2012 | language = Russian | description = }}{{check source|date=August 2012}}</ref>
In 1751, a mass fist fight took place on a street in [[Saint Petersburg]], which came to the attention of Empress [[Elizabeth of Russia]]. After that the Empress forbade the organization of fist fights on the territory of [[Moscow]] and Saint Petersburg.<ref name="Русская цивилизация" />
During the reign of [[Catherine the Great]], the popularity of fist fighting was growing again,<ref name="Интернет-портал «Легендарный Физтех», «Физтех-центр»" /> and it is said that Count [[Orlov (family)|Orlov]] was a good fist fighter himself and even invited notable fist fighters to compare powers.<ref name="Интернет-портал «Легендарный Физтех», «Физтех-центр»" />
In 1832, [[Nicholas I of Russia]] completely forbade fist fights as "harmful fun".<ref name="Русская цивилизация" />
==Legacy== In 1941 the most important then [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] specialist in [[Boxing]], K.V. Gradopolov, wrote a book about the right way to fight with fists. In that book, he offered a new exercise, called "group boxing", and he mentioned it was an [[ancient Rus]]sian sport (what he was talking about, was the "Stenka na Stenku" version).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.infosport.ru/Press/SZR/0798/topic1.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-08-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080822012307/http://www.infosport.ru/Press/SZR/0798/topic1.htm |archivedate=2008-08-22 |df= }} "1941 году ведущий советский специалист по боксу К. В. Градополов рассказывал в своей книге о методах обучения воинов кулачному прикладному искусству. Предлагалось там такое необычное упражнение, как «групповой бокс». Автор прямо указывал, что «прообразом группового бокса (организованного и ограниченного определенными правилами) является русский самобытный народный спорт «стенка на стенку». (In 1941 the leading Soviet specialist in boxing K.V. Gradopolov told in his box about methods to teach soldiers how to fight with fists. He there offered a new exercise, 'group boxing'. He said there that the prototype of the 'group boxing' was the Russian folk sport "Wall on Wall"] {{cite web |url=http://www.infosport.ru/Press/SZR/0798/topic1.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-08-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080117155052/http://www.infosport.ru/Press/SZR/0798/topic1.htm |archivedate=January 17, 2008 |df= }}</ref>
==Rules and types== Every region in [[Russia]] incorporated different rules unlike the sport of boxing. In some places they fought with bare arms, while in other they stretched the sleeves over the fists. There were cases where participants would cheat by putting iron under their sleeves.<ref>Sakharov, Ivan P., ''Сказания русского народа'', p. 129. "Часто случалось, что хитрые и слабые бойцы закладывали в рукавицы бабки-чугунки для поражения противников. [Often it occurred, that weak fighters inserted iron into their sleeves]"</ref>
There are three types of Russian fist fighting: the first is the singles type, a one-on-one fight; the second type is a team fight also known as "wall on wall". The third one, "catch drop", was the least practiced.<ref>Sakharov, Ivan P., ''Сказания русского народа'', p. 129. "Кулачные бои совершались разными видами. Более всех почитался: бой один на один, за ним—стена на стену, а менее всех сцеплялка-свалка. [There were different types of fist fighting. The most famous was a one-on-one, after that the wall on wall, and the least famous was the catch-drop."]</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.infosport.ru/Press/SZR/0798/topic1.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-08-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080822012307/http://www.infosport.ru/Press/SZR/0798/topic1.htm |archivedate=2008-08-22 |df= }} "Кулачный бой практиковался у нас в трех формах: один на один («сам на сам»), стенка на стенку и «сцеплялка–свалка». [Fist fighting was practiced in three ways. One-on-one, wall on wall, and catch-drop."] {{cite web |url=http://www.infosport.ru/Press/SZR/0798/topic1.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-08-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080117155052/http://www.infosport.ru/Press/SZR/0798/topic1.htm |archivedate=January 17, 2008 |df= }}</ref> There were several versions of the singles fight. One version was like modern boxing, where one fighter hits the other wherever he wants or can. The other version is when the fighters take turns hitting each other. Escaping from a punch, answering it not on turn, and moving aside were not allowed; all that could be done was to use the hands to try to protect one's own body.<ref>Labzyuk, Sergei, "Историческая справка: кулачный бой". "Также существовал кулачный бой 'удар на удар' или 'раз за раз', когда противники наносили удары по очереди. Уклоняться от удара, отвечать на него, переступать ногами запрещалось, можно было лишь прикрыть руками наиболее уязвимые места. [There was also a fist fighting type 'hit on hit' or 'one for one', when the opponents gave punches on turn. Evading a punch, answering it not on turn, moving one's legs was not allowed. All could be done was to use the hands to try to protect the more painful areas]"</ref> Victory could come in few cases: when one of the fighters falls, till first blood, or till one of the fighters gives up.<ref>Labzyuk, Sergei, "Историческая справка: кулачный бой". "Бились по различным правилам: - до сбивания на землю ударом (до трех сбиваний) - до первой крови - до сдачи противника и признания своего поражения. Также существовал кулачный бой 'удар на удар' или 'раз за раз', когда противники наносили удары по очереди. Уклоняться от удара, отвечать на него, переступать ногами запрещалось, можно было лишь прикрыть руками наиболее уязвимые места. [There were different types of rules. 1. Till one falls. 2. Till first blood. 3. Till one gives up.]"</ref>
The "wall-on-wall" fight (with anywhere from dozen to several hundreds participants) was performed strictly by rules and could go on for hours. Both "walls" had a chief fighter, who served as a tactician and a commanding officer. "Walls" themselves were tight straight formations 3-4 ranks deep. Repeated attacks were performed, aiming to push the opposing "wall" out of the game area. Basic tactics were used, such as breaching using heavy fighters (who were usually held in reserve), encircling, false retreat and others; but as a rule, tight wall formation never broke. Tactics also included battle planning. The "wall-on-wall" fights, while performed for entertainment, were in fact close to military training. For example, notable ethnographer V. Gilyarovsky recalled that during his voluntary service in an infantry regiment soldiers often staged wall-on-wall fistfights with factory workers.<ref>[http://www.infosport.ru/Press/SZR/0798/topic1.htm Кулачный бой на Руси ''Спортивная жизнь'' magazine, No. 7 1998] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080117155052/http://www.infosport.ru/Press/SZR/0798/topic1.htm |date=January 17, 2008 }}</ref>
A famous phrase in [[Russian language|Russian]], "Do not hit a man when he's down", has roots in that sport.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.infosport.ru/Press/SZR/0798/topic1.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-08-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080822012307/http://www.infosport.ru/Press/SZR/0798/topic1.htm |archivedate=2008-08-22 |df= }} "Одно из правил кулачного боя стало даже пословицей, символизирующей русское благородство в бою: «Лежачего не бьют». [One of the rules of fist fighting even turned into a well-known phrase, which showed the Russian nobility: "Do not hit a man when he's down."] {{cite web |url=http://www.infosport.ru/Press/SZR/0798/topic1.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-08-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080117155052/http://www.infosport.ru/Press/SZR/0798/topic1.htm |archivedate=January 17, 2008 |df= }}</ref>
==Fist fighting in Russian popular culture== [[File:Vasnetsov Kulachni boi.jpg|thumb|150px|"Fistfight" (''Kulachniy Boy''), a painting by [[Viktor Vasnetsov]].]]
As for centuries fist fighting was so popular and was such a part of Russian folk life,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.infosport.ru/Press/SZR/0798/topic1.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-08-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080822012307/http://www.infosport.ru/Press/SZR/0798/topic1.htm |archivedate=2008-08-22 |df= }} "Широчайшей географией кулачных боев, их повсеместным распространением объяснялось то, что кроме русских в них со временем стали принимать участие и представители иных национальностей, обитавших в России: древняя чудь, татары, мордовцы. И многие другие." (The wide territory the fist fight was practiced on brought the sport to other nations like the Tatars, Mordvins, and many others) {{cite web |url=http://www.infosport.ru/Press/SZR/0798/topic1.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-08-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080822012307/http://www.infosport.ru/Press/SZR/0798/topic1.htm |archivedate=August 22, 2008 |df= }}</ref> it occurred frequently in [[Russian literature]] and [[Russian art|art]].
The most famous portrayal of a Russian fistfight is in [[Mikhail Lermontov]]'s poem, The Song of the Merchant Kalashnikov. There, the fistfight tales place as a form of honor [[duel]] between an [[oprichnik]] (government police agent) and a merchant. It is notable that, according to Lermontov, both characters use combat gloves ('rukavitsy' — reinforced mittens). Though it may be an example of poetic license, the poem states that the first connected blow by Kalashnikov bent a large bronze cross hanging from his opponent's neck, and the second fractured the opponent's temple, killing him. The fight also features in the [[opera]] ''[[The Merchant Kalashnikov (opera)|The Merchant Kalashnikov]]'' by [[Anton Rubinstein]] (1880).
In the 19th century [[Sergei Aksakov]] watched famous fist fights in the Kaban frozen lake in [[Kazan]], and later wrote about them in his "Story about student life". Some decades later, at the same lake, the young future opera-singer [[Feodor Chaliapin]] took part in a similar fight: "From one side came we, the [[Russians]] of [[Kazan]], from the other side the [[Tatars]]. We fought hard without feeling sorry for ourselves, but never broke the historic rules of not to hit one that is already down, not to kick, and not to keep iron up one's sleeves".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.infosport.ru/Press/SZR/0798/topic1.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-08-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080822012307/http://www.infosport.ru/Press/SZR/0798/topic1.htm |archivedate=2008-08-22 |df= }} "Еще в 1806 году С. Т. Аксаков наблюдал знаменитые кулачные бои в Казани, на льду озера Кабан, и впоследствии описал их в своем «Рассказе о студенческой жизни». А через восемь десятилетий в тех же боях азартно дрался великий русский артист Ф. И. Шаляпин. Уже увенчанный мировой славой, он делился дорогими его сердцу воспоминаниями: «Сходились с одной стороны мы, казанская Русь, с другой - добродушные татары. Дрались отчаянно, не щадя ни себя, ни противников. Но и в горячке яростной битвы никогда не нарушали установленных искони правил: лежачего не бить, присевшего на корточки - тоже, ногами не драться, тяжести в рукавицы не прятать»." {{cite web |url=http://www.infosport.ru/Press/SZR/0798/topic1.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-08-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080117155052/http://www.infosport.ru/Press/SZR/0798/topic1.htm |archivedate=January 17, 2008 |df= }}</ref> Later, the young Chaliapin was attacked in a fight over a girl, but thanks to knowing fist fighting he won. He wrote: "He jumped to beat me, and even though I was afraid of the police, learning fist fighting at the frozen lakes of [[Kazan]] helped me, and he humiliatingly lost".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.infosport.ru/Press/SZR/0798/topic1.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-08-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080822012307/http://www.infosport.ru/Press/SZR/0798/topic1.htm |archivedate=2008-08-22 |df= }} "Однажды, когда Федор уже начал взрослеть, навыки кулачного боя выручили его в критической ситуации. Его несчастный соперник в любви - городовой - попытался было поколотить начинающего хориста, но тот вовсе не забыл, как хаживал в стенке на озере Кабан, и крепко проучил блюстителя порядка. «Он бросился бить меня. Но хотя я очень боялся полиции, однако опыт казанских кулачных боев послужил мне на пользу, и городовой был посрамлен»." {{cite web |url=http://www.infosport.ru/Press/SZR/0798/topic1.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-08-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080117155052/http://www.infosport.ru/Press/SZR/0798/topic1.htm |archivedate=January 17, 2008 |df= }}</ref>
The Russian poet [[Sergei Yesenin]] in his autobiography notes "About myself" told that his grandfather taught him fist fighting.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.infosport.ru/Press/SZR/0798/topic1.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-08-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080822012307/http://www.infosport.ru/Press/SZR/0798/topic1.htm |archivedate=2008-08-22 |df= }} "«Дедушка иногда сам поддразнивал на кулачку и часто говорил бабке: «Ты у меня, дура, его не трожь, он так крепче будет!». Так написал сам поэт в автобиографических заметках «О себе»." (Sometimes my grandfather teased me to fist fight and told my grandmother: "You, my stupid, don't touch him. That way he'll be tougher". That's what the poet himself wrote in the autobiographic notes "About Myself") {{cite web |url=http://www.infosport.ru/Press/SZR/0798/topic1.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-08-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080117155052/http://www.infosport.ru/Press/SZR/0798/topic1.htm |archivedate=January 17, 2008 |df= }}</ref>
One of the heroes in the book "Thief" by the [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] novelist [[Leonid Leonov]] said: "In childhood, it happened, only in fist fights I found real friends... And was never wrong! Because only in a fight the whole human nature comes out".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.infosport.ru/Press/SZR/0798/topic1.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-08-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080822012307/http://www.infosport.ru/Press/SZR/0798/topic1.htm |archivedate=2008-08-22 |df= }} "Один из героев его романа «Вор» говорит: «В мальчишестве, бывало, только на кулашнике и подберешь себе приятеля... И ведь ни разу не ошибался! Это оттого, что именно в бою «вся людская повадка насквозь видна»." (One of the heroes in the book "Thief" by the [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] novelist [[Leonid Leonov]] said: "In childhood, it happened, only in fist fights I found real friends... And was never wrong! Because only in a fight the whole human nature comes out") {{cite web |url=http://www.infosport.ru/Press/SZR/0798/topic1.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-08-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080822012307/http://www.infosport.ru/Press/SZR/0798/topic1.htm |archivedate=August 22, 2008 |df= }}</ref>
Claims have been made that the [[Russian nobility]] favoured fistfights over duels, but on the other hand it has been suggested that the nobility actually were against fistfights and preferred weapons.<ref>{{cite journal|url=https://www.jstor.org/pss/3086132 |title=On the Russian Duel: Problems of Interpretation |first=Franca |last=Beltrame |journal=The Slavic and East European Journal |volume=45 |issue=4 |pages=741–746 |quote=There was a claim brought up that the Russian nobility preferred fistfights over duels, which is a lie because they have seen fist fighting as disgraceful |doi=10.2307/3086132}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Bare-knuckle boxing]] * [[Burmese bareknuckle boxing]]
==References== ;Notes {{reflist|2}}
;Works cited *{{cite web|url=http://fist.com.ua/history/fisticuffs.php |accessdate=1 August 2012 |script-title=ru:Историческая справка: кулачный бой |trans-title=Historical note: Fist fighting |language=Russian |first=Sergei |last=Labzyuk |publisher=Federation of Kyiv Slavonic Fist Fighters}} *{{cite web|url=http://istina.rin.ru/cgi-bin/print.pl?sait=6&id=2855 |language=Russian |accessdate=1 August 2012 |title=Русский кулачный бой |trans-title= Russian Fist Fighting |work=Боевые искусства}} *{{cite book|url=http://bibliotekar.ru/rusSaharov/129.htm |script-title=ru:Сказания русского народа |trans-title=Russian Folk Tales |language=Russian |first=Ivan Petrovich |last=Sakharov |year=1885 |publisher=A. S. Suborin |chapter=<nowiki>Сказания о русских народных играх: Кулачный бой [Tales of Russian folk games: pugilism]</nowiki> |page=129}}
==External links== {{Commons category|Russian fist fighting}} * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3TZDwPOTm0U Fist fighting in USSR (Rare video)] * [http://bibliotekar.ru/rusSaharov/129.htm About the sport from the Russian ethnic games collection] (Russian) * [https://web.archive.org/web/20080822012307/http://www.infosport.ru/Press/SZR/0798/topic1.htm Fist fighting in ancient Rus] (Russian) * [http://www.skb-nabchelny.boom.ru/ A fist fighting fan-club] (Russian) * [http://fist.com.ua/ Kievan federation of fist fighting] (Ukrainian)(Russian) * [http://www.books4all.ru/description/1205.html A downloadable book about Russian fist fighting] (Russian) * [http://istina.rin.ru/cgi-bin/print.pl?sait=6&id=2855 An article about the Russian fist fighting] (Russian)

revision.text:
{{context|date=April 2018}} [[Image:Shocking Duel.jpg|thumb|right|Game in progress]] '''Shocking Duel''' is a [[game]] of [[pain]] [[endurance]] in which each [[Player (game)|player]] grips one of a pair of connected handles which deliver [[electric shock]]s of increasing intensity. The loser is the first player to release their handle.<ref>{{cite web|title=Shocking Duel: Bring On The Pain|url=http://www.ohgizmo.com/2007/03/19/shocking-duel-bring-on-the-pain/|date=March 19, 2007|author=Evan Ackerman|publisher=Oh Gizmo!}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.i4u.com/article8261.html|title=Shocking Duel Game Brings the Pain|date=19 March 2007|author=Shane McGlaun}}</ref><ref>{{citation|publisher=The Oak Ridger|author=Betsy Abernathy|date=October 12, 2006|title=Games that are (really) shocking}}</ref>
==Reception== Pau Waelder studied similar games which delivered electric shocks to the opponent through a variety of interfaces; games such as ''[[PainStation]]'', ''Legshocker'', ''Tekken Torture'' and ''Tazer Tag''. They were generally found to be popular or even addictive. He wrote, "What many players find in these games of pain is what many people in Western society are looking for in more or less sublimated forms: an engaging experience that involves both body and mind, a way to release aggressiveness in a harmless manner, a social intercourse, a chance to demonstrate one's self-efficacy before others, a different form of competition. ... pain is present here not just as a punishment, but especially as a threat. It is the threat of experiencing pain that puts the player in a state of alert, and being in this state is felt to be exciting and fun."<ref>{{citation |title=Games of Pain |author=Pau Waelder Laso |journal=[[Leonardo (journal)|Leonardo]] |volume=40 |number=3 |year=2007 |pages=239–242 |jstor=20206411 |publisher=[[MIT Press]] |doi=10.1162/leon.2007.40.3.238|url=https://zenodo.org/record/1137676/files/article.pdf }}</ref>
==Safety== The manufacturer's [[safety]] warning advises that the game may interfere with [[pacemaker]]s and other electronic health equipment and that it should not be played by sufferers from [[epilepsy]] or [[heart disease|heart conditions]].<ref>{{citation|title=Warning|publisher=Paladone Products Ltd}}</ref>
==See also==
* [[Induction coil]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links==
[[Category:Games of physical skill]] [[Category:2000s toys]] [[Category:Endurance games]]
{{Game-stub}}

{{Infobox Figure Skating Element |image= |imagesize= |caption= |element name= Spread eagle |alt name= |scoring abbrev= |element type= [[Moves in the field]] |edges= |take off edge= |landing edge= |inventor= |named for= |disciplines= }} The '''spread eagle''' is one of the [[moves in the field]] in the sport of [[figure skating]], in which a skater glides on both feet, the toes turned out to the sides, heels facing each other. It can be performed on either the inside or outside edges. It is commonly used as an entrance to jumps, adding to the difficulty level of that jump under the [[ISU Judging System|Code of Points]]. It is most commonly used an entrance to an [[axel jump]]. ==Gallery== ===Single=== Image:Spread_eagle_inside.jpg|
An inside spread eagle
front view
([[Jeffrey Buttle]])
File:Vitali Sazonets 2007 Nebelhorn Trophy.jpg|
An inside spread eagle
side view
([[Vitali Sazonets]])
File:2013 World Championships Mao Asada FP.jpg|
An inside spread eagle ([[Mao Asada]])
Image:AGriazev 2007 Mytischi.jpg|
An outside spread eagle
([[Andrei Griazev]])
Image:Zhang 2008SC by Carmichael.jpg|
An outside spread eagle
([[Caroline Zhang]])
 ===Pairs=== Image:Kavaguti and Smirnov 2009 Worlds Gala.jpg|
An outside spread eagle
([[Yuko Kavaguti]] & [[Alexander Smirnov (figure skater)|Alexander Smirnov]])
Image:Maria Mukhortova and Maxim Trankov at 2010 European Championships (4).jpg|
A carry lift with the man in a spread eagle
([[Maria Mukhortova]] & [[Maxim Trankov]])
 ===Ice dancing=== Image:Ice_dancing_spread_eagle_lift.jpg|
The male skater performs an outside spread eagle
([[Isabelle Delobel]] & [[Olivier Schoenfelder]])
Image:Lynn Kriengkrairut & Logan Giulietti-Schmitt 2007 Nebelhorn Trophy.jpg|
The male skater performs an outside spread eagle
([[Lynn Kriengkrairut]] & [[Logan Giulietti-Schmitt]])
Image:Kristina Gorshkova & Vitali Butikov 2005 Croatia Cup.jpg|
inside and outside
([[Kristina Gorshkova]] & [[Vitali Butikov]])
 ===Synchronized skating=== Image:Hockettes 2007.jpg|
outside spread eagles
(The Hockettes)
 ==External links== {{commons category|Spread eagles}} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20070510223200/http://sdsd.essortment.com/figureskatingt_rlrg.htm Read more about Spread eagles] {{Figure skating}} [[Category:Figure skating elements|Spread eagle]] {{figure-skating-stub}}
