{{Use mdy dates|date=April 2014}} {{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = The Palace of Auburn Hills | logo_image = The Palace of Auburn Hills.svg | image = Palace Of Auburn Hills Michigan.jpg | address = 6 Championship Drive{{cite web|title=PALACE SPORTS & ENTERTAINMENT|url=http://www.palacenet.com|website=Palacenet.com|accessdate=April 26, 2017}} | location = [[Auburn Hills, Michigan]], U.S. | coordinates = {{Coord|42|41|49|N|83|14|44|W|type:landmark_scale:1000|display=it}} | broke_ground = June 7, 1986{{cite news |title=Pistons Plan to Vacate Silverdome for Auburn Hills| first=Geoffrey| last=Haynes| url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=0EQiAAAAIBAJ&sjid=-asFAAAAIBAJ&pg=1310,3244416&dq=en| newspaper=[[The Argus-Press]]| date=June 7, 1986| accessdate=February 20, 2012}} | built = | opened = August 13, 1988{{cite web|url=http://www.sportsbusinessdaily.com/Journal/Issues/2008/11/20081103/This-Weeks-News/Twenty-Years-In-The-Palace-Still-Shines.aspx|title=Twenty years in, the Palace still shines| work=Sports Business Daily| first=Don| last=Muret| date=November 3, 2008| accessdate=February 22, 2017}} | renovated = 2005, 2015 | closed = October 12, 2017 | demolished = | owner = [[Tom Gores]]{{cite news| url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/alanaglass/2012/07/30/tom-gores-puts-his-stamp-on-the-detroit-pistons-with-arena-renovations/| work=[[Forbes]]| first=Alana| last=Glass| date=July 30, 2012| title=Tom Gores Puts His Stamp On The Detroit Pistons With Arena Renovations}} | operator = [[Palace Sports and Entertainment|Palace Sports & Entertainment]] | construction_cost = [[United States dollar|$]]90 million
(${{formatprice|{{Inflation|US|90000000|1988}}}} in {{Inflation-year|US}} dollars{{inflation-fn|US}}) | architect = [[Rossetti Architects]]{{cite web|first=Carlos|last=Monarrez|title=The story of the Palace of Auburn Hills: Somehow, it worked|url=http://www.freep.com/story/sports/nba/pistons/2017/04/10/palace-of-auburn-hills-history/100258662/|website=Detroit Free Press|date=April 10, 2017|accessdate=April 11, 2017}} | project_manager = Frank Rewold and Sons{{cite web| url=http://basketball.ballparks.com/NBA/DetroitPistons/index.htm| title=Palace of Auburn Hills| first1=Paul| last1=Munsey| first2=Cory| last2=Suppes| publisher=Ballparks.com| accessdate=September 22, 2016}} | structural engineer = McClerg & Associates Inc.http://www.pci.org/view_file.cfm?file=JL-91-JANUARY-FEBRUARY-3.pdf{{dead link|date=November 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} | general_contractor = R.E. Dailey & Company{{cite web| url=http://www.emporis.com/building/streetpalaceofauburnhills-auburnhills-mi-usa| title=The Palace of Auburn Hills| publisher=Emporis| accessdate=February 22, 2017}} | capacity = Basketball: 22,076{{cite web|url=http://www.nba.com/pistons/history/thepalaceofauburnhills.html/|title=The Palace of Auburn Hills|website=Detroit Pistons}}{{cite web|url=http://www.insidearenas.com/eastern/PalaceatAuburnHills.htm|title=Palace at Auburn Hills|date=January 8, 2018|publisher=}}{{cite web| title=The Palace of Auburn Hills| url=https://www.palacenet.com/venues-events/palace-of-auburn-hills| website=Palace Sports & Entertainment; Palace Facts| accessdate=June 29, 2016| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160611184045/https://www.palacenet.com/venues-events/palace-of-auburn-hills| archive-date=June 11, 2016| dead-url=yes| df=mdy-all}}
Ice hockey: 20,804
Concerts: 6,000 to 24,276 | tenants = [[Detroit Pistons]] ([[National Basketball Association|NBA]]) (1988–2017)
[[Detroit Vipers]] ([[International Hockey League (1945-2001)|IHL]]) (1994–2001)
[[Detroit Safari]] ([[Continental Indoor Soccer League|CISL]]) (1994–1997)
[[Detroit Whalers]] ([[Ontario Hockey League|OHL]]) (1995–1996)
[[Detroit Rockers]] ([[National Professional Soccer League II|NPSL]]) (1997–2000)
[[Detroit Shock]] ([[Women's National Basketball Association|WNBA]]) (1998–2009)
[[Detroit Fury]] ([[Arena Football League|AFL]]) (2001–2004)}} '''The Palace of Auburn Hills''', commonly referred to as '''The Palace''', is a defunct multi-purpose arena located in [[Auburn Hills, Michigan]]. It was the home of the [[Detroit Pistons]] of the [[National Basketball Association]] (NBA), the [[Detroit Shock]] of the [[Women's National Basketball Association]] (WNBA), the [[Detroit Vipers]] of the [[International Hockey League (1945-2001)|International Hockey League]], the [[Detroit Safari]] of the [[Continental Indoor Soccer League]], and the [[Detroit Fury]] of the [[Arena Football League (1987-2008)|Arena Football League]]. The Palace was one of eight basketball arenas owned by their respective NBA franchises. ==Etymology== By the time it closed as an NBA venue, the Palace was one of only two [[List of National Basketball Association arenas|arenas]] which had not sold its naming rights to a corporate sponsor. The other was [[Madison Square Garden]]. The Pistons court was previously named the "William Davidson Court", in honor of the late owner, prior to the home opener on October 28, 2009; however, Davidson's signature, along with the retired numbers, were removed from the hardwood when [[Tom Gores]] took over ownership of the Palace, and were re-retired instead atop the Palace rafters as replacement banners. ==History== [[File:Palace of Auburn Hills.jpg|thumb|The interior of the Palace of Auburn Hills during a Detroit Pistons basketball game in January 2006.]] ===Background=== From 1957 to 1978, the Pistons competed in Detroit's [[Detroit Olympia|Olympia Stadium]], [[Calihan Hall|Memorial Building]], and [[Cobo Center#Cobo Arena|Cobo Arena]]. In 1978, owner [[Bill Davidson (businessman)|Bill Davidson]] elected not to share the new [[Joe Louis Arena]] with the [[Detroit Red Wings]], and instead chose to relocate the team to the [[Pontiac Silverdome]], a venue constructed for [[American football|football]], where they remained for the next decade. While the Silverdome could accommodate massive crowds, it offered substandard sight lines for basketball viewing. In late 1985, a group led by Davidson decided to build a new arena in Auburn Hills. Groundbreaking for the arena took place in June 1986. Using entirely private funding, The Palace cost a relatively low price of $90 million. The Davidson family held a controlling interest in the arena until [[Tom Gores]] bought it as part of his purchase of the Pistons in 2011. ===Construction=== Then-Pistons owner William Davidson and two developers privately financed the $90 million construction of The Palace, and did not require public funds. The Palace was built with 180 [[luxury box|luxury suites]], considered an exorbitant number when it opened, but it has consistently managed to lease virtually all of them. In December 2005, the Palace added five underground luxury suites, each containing {{convert|450|sqft|m2}} of space and renting for $450,000 per year. Eight more luxury suites, also located below arena level, were opened in February 2006. They range in size from {{convert|800|to|1200|sqft|m2}} and rent for $350,000 annually.{{cite news| url=http://www.sportsbusinessdaily.com/Journal/Issues/2005/02/20050228/Facilities/Pistons-Spend-Big-To-Land-The-Big-Spenders.aspx?hl=Pistons%20spend%20big%20to%20land%20the%20big%20spenders&sc=0| title=Pistons spend big to land the big spenders| first=John| last=Lombardo| work=Sports Business Journal| date=February 28, 2005| accessdate=February 22, 2017}} The architectural design of the Palace, including its multiple tiers of luxury suites, has been used as the basis for many other professional sports arenas in North America since its construction, including the [[Canadian Tire Centre]] in [[Ottawa]], also designed by Rossetti Associates.{{cite web| url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nba/news/story?id=2889956&campaign=rss&source=NBAHeadlines| title=Last of its kind: Charlotte Coliseum to be demolished Sunday| publisher=[[ESPN]]| agency=Associated Press}} ===Basketball=== The Palace opened in 1988. When one of The Palace's basketball occupants won a championship, the number on its address changed. Its current address is 6 Championship Drive, reflecting the Pistons' three NBA titles and the Detroit Shock's three WNBA titles (the Detroit Vipers' 1997 [[International Hockey League (1945-2001)|Turner Cup]] championship has not been officially recognized in the arena's address; the address also remained unchanged despite the Shock's move to [[Tulsa Shock|Tulsa, Oklahoma]] in 2010; they moved to [[Dallas, Texas]] in 2016, and are now known as the [[Dallas Wings]]). The original address was 3777 Lapeer Road. The Palace was widely considered to be the first of the modern-style NBA arenas, and its large number of luxury suites was a major reason for the building boom of new NBA arenas in the 1990s. Although the Palace became one of the oldest arenas in the NBA, its foresighted design contained the amenities that most NBA teams have sought in new arenas built since that time. By contrast, of the other NBA venues that opened in 1988-89, [[Amway Arena]], [[Charlotte Coliseum]], and [[Miami Arena]] have been demolished, while the [[Bradley Center]] and [[Sleep Train Arena]] have been replaced, with the former scheduled to be demolished starting in September 2018. All of these arenas were rendered obsolete by the lack of luxury suites and [[club seating]], lucrative revenue-generating features that made pro sports teams financially successful in order to remain competitive long-term, and also being located in suburban rather than downtown areas (the Palace, however, remained one of the successful suburban arenas).{{cite web| url=http://palaceofauburnhills.stadiumhotelnetwork.com/information.html| title=Auburn Hills Information| publisher=Stadium Hotel Network| accessdate=February 22, 2017}}{{cite news |url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=IG&p_theme=ig&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&s_dispstring=Nothin'%20But%20Profit:%20Winning%20no%20longer%20key%20to%20new%20NBA%20AND%20date(all)&p_field_advanced-0=&p_text_advanced-0=(Nothin'%20But%20Profit:%20Winning%20no%20longer%20key%20to%20new%20NBA)&xcal_numdocs=20&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&xcal_useweights=no |title=Nothin' But Profit: Winning no longer key to new NBA |publisher=[[Seattle Post-Intelligencer]]| date=May 15, 2006| accessdate=February 22, 2017| subscription=yes| first1=Mike| last1=Lewis| first2=Phuong| last2=Cat Le}} Nonetheless, Palace Sports & Entertainment (PS&E) had spent $117.5 million in upgrades and renovations to keep the arena updated. A new high definition [[JumboTron]] monitor, new LED video monitors, and more than {{convert|950|ft|m}} of ribbon display technology from [[Daktronics]] was installed in the mid-2000s.{{cite web |url=http://www.nba.com/pistons/news/ledboards.html |title=PISTONS: The Palace of Auburn Hills Installs Light Emitting Diode Boards in Arena| publisher=NBA}} ====Malice at the Palace==== {{main|Pacers–Pistons brawl}} On November 19, 2004, a fight broke–out between members of the NBA's Detroit Pistons and [[Indiana Pacers]]. As the on-court fight died down, a fan threw a cup of [[Diet Coke]] at Pacers forward [[Metta World Peace|Ron Artest]], who then rushed into the crowd, sparking a melee between players and spectators. The fight resulted in the suspension of nine players, criminal charges against five players, and criminal charges against five spectators. The offending fans were banned from attending games at The Palace. In the aftermath of the fight, the NBA decided to increase the security presence between players and spectators. The fact that the fight took place at The Palace of Auburn Hills led to it becoming colloquially referred to as "Malice at the Palace" and "Basketbrawl". The Palace was also the site of a brawl between the WNBA's [[Sparks–Shock brawl|Shock and Sparks]] on July 21, 2008. ===Notable concerts=== [[Aerosmith]] played the venue 14 times from 1990-2012.https://www.setlist.fm/search?query=Aerosmith+Auburn+Hills [[Michael Jackson]] performed three sold-out shows during his [[Bad World Tour]] on October 24-26, 1988. [[Pink Floyd]] performed there on 16 and 17 August 1988 as part of their [[A Momentary Lapse of Reason Tour|A Momentary lapse of Reason Tour]]. [[Bon Jovi]] performed during their [[Keep The Faith]] world tour on March 2nd, 1993, their [[Crush Tour]] on November 18, 2000 and their Lost Highway Tour on February 20, 2008. [[Van Halen]] performed 3 shows on their [[For Unlawful Carnal Knowledge Tour]] on February 21, 1992 and consecutive shows on April 3rd and 4th, 1992. They also performed consecutive shows during their [[The Balance "Ambulance" Tour]] on April 15th and 16th, 1995. [[Sting (musician)|Sting]] performed during his [[...Nothing Like the Sun]] Tour on August 13, 1988, becoming the very first musical act to perform at The Palace.{{cite web|url=http://www.police.cybercomm.nl/s19880813.htm|title=Sting - Concert information|publisher=|accessdate=September 22, 2016}} [[The Cure]] performed two consecutive shows, during their [[Wish (The Cure album)|Wish]] Tour on July 18–19, 1992, with The [[Cranes (band)|Cranes]] as their opening act. The shows were recorded and released as a live album, entitled ''[[Show (The Cure album)|Show]]''.{{cn|date=December 2017}} [[Grand Funk Railroad]] performed a benefit show for the nation of [[Bosnia and Herzegovina]] in March 1997 during their Reunion Tour. The show also featured [[Peter Frampton]], [[Alto Reed]], [[Paul Shaffer]], and the [[Detroit Symphony Orchestra]]. The performance was recorded, and released as the double-live [[Bosnia (album)|Bosnia]] album in October of that year. The Palace was the site of an attempt on the life of [[Led Zeppelin]] guitarist [[Jimmy Page]], while he was on tour, with former band mate [[Robert Plant]], during their [[No Quarter: Jimmy Page and Robert Plant Unledded|No Quarter]] Tour.{{cite news| url=http://articles.nydailynews.com/1995-04-05/entertainment/17973065_1_jimmy-page-willie-nelson-drug-charges| work=[[New York Daily News]]| first=David| last=Hinckley| title=Extra! Extra! Late-breaking News From The World Of Entertainment| date=April 5, 1995}} On March 31, 1995, Lance Alworth Cunningham, a 23-year-old, who thought that Led Zeppelin music contained "satanic messages", tried rushing the stage with a knife. He waited until the song "[[Kashmir (song)|Kashmir]]" started and then made his charge for the stage, waving the weapon. The man was tackled by patrons and security about 50 feet from the stage. [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]] performed two sold–out shows during her [[Drowned World Tour]] on August 25–26, 2001. The shows were recorded and broadcast live on [[HBO]] and were later released as a DVD, entitled ''[[Drowned World Tour 2001]]''. ===Future=== In October 2016, it was reported that the Pistons' ownership were negotiating a possible relocation to [[Little Caesars Arena]], a new multi-purpose venue located in [[Midtown Detroit]] built by [[Olympia Entertainment]] to replace Joe Louis Arena as home of the [[National Hockey League|NHL]]'s [[Detroit Red Wings]], as soon as the [[2017–18 Detroit Pistons season|2017–18 season]].{{cite web| first=Derick| last=Hutchinson| url=http://www.clickondetroit.com/sports/detroit-pistons-finalizing-deal-to-move-downtown-sources-say| title=Detroit Pistons finalizing deal to move downtown, sources say| work=[[WDIV-TV]] News| publisher=Graham Media Group| date=October 26, 2016| accessdate=October 30, 2016 }}{{cite web| first=Vince| last=Ellis| title=Detroit Pistons hammering out 2 key issues for downtown arena move| url=http://www.freep.com/story/sports/nba/pistons/2016/10/26/detroit-pistons-move-downtown/92770520/| work=[[Detroit Free Press]]| date=October 26, 2016| accessdate=October 29, 2016}}{{cite web| first=Vince| last=Ellis| title=Tom Gores confirms Pistons 'very close' to move downtown, and soon| url=http://www.freep.com/story/sports/nba/pistons/2016/10/28/detroit-pistons-move-downtown-tom-gores/92911674/| work=Detroit Free Press| date=October 29, 2016| accessdate=October 29, 2016}} On November 22, 2016, the team officially announced that the Pistons would play at Little Caesars Arena in 2017.{{cite web| url=http://www.nba.com/pistons/news/pistons-move-downtown-detroit| title=Pistons to Move to Downtown Detroit| website=Pistons.com| date=November 22, 2016| accessdate=November 22, 2016}}{{cite web| first1=Brian| last1=Manzullo| first2=John| last2=Gallagher| first3=Joe| last3=Guillen| title=Detroit Pistons moving downtown: 'We want to be all in on Detroit'|url=http://www.freep.com/story/sports/nba/pistons/2016/11/22/detroit-pistons-downtown/94279874/| work=Detroit Free Press| date=November 22, 2016| accessdate=November 22, 2016}}{{cite web| first=Tony| last=Paul| title=‘The right move’: Pistons returning to Detroit|url=http://www.detroitnews.com/story/sports/nba/pistons/2016/11/22/pistons-tellem-we-want-all-detroit/94291544/| work=[[The Detroit News]]| date=November 22, 2016| accessdate=November 22, 2016}} The final NBA game at The Palace was played on April 10, 2017, with the Pistons losing to the [[Washington Wizards]], 105-101.{{cite web|first=Vince|last=Ellis|title=Pistons close Palace with 105-101 loss to Wizards|url=http://www.freep.com/story/sports/nba/pistons/2017/04/10/detroit-pistons-washington-wizards/100312886/|website=Detroit Free Press|date=April 10, 2017|accessdate=April 11, 2017}}{{cite web|first=Rod|last=Beard|title=Pistons’ rally falls short in last game at Palace|url=http://www.detroitnews.com/story/sports/nba/pistons/2017/04/10/pistons-rally-falls-short-last-game-palace/100313978/|website=The Detroit News|date=April 10, 2017|accessdate=April 11, 2017}} That game ended a 42-year history of professional sports in [[Oakland County, Michigan|Oakland County]], dating back to the [[Detroit Lions|Detroit Lions']] first game at the nearby [[Pontiac Silverdome]] in 1975. On August 24, 2017, it was announced that Bob Seger would hold the final concert at the venue on September 23, 2017.{{cite web|url=http://www.freep.com/story/entertainment/2017/08/24/palace-auburn-hills-closing-bob-seger/569388001/|title=Confirmed: Palace of Auburn Hills is closing; Bob Seger to be final event|publisher=}} The last scheduled event at the venue was the Taste of Auburn Hills on October 12, 2017. Palace Sports & Entertainment entered into a joint venture with Olympia known as [[313 Presents]] to jointly manage entertainment bookings and promotions for Little Caesars Arena and other venues owned by the firms.{{cite web|first=Adam|last=Graham|title=Palace, Olympia staffs form new venture, 313 Presents|url=http://www.detroitnews.com/story/entertainment/2017/10/08/palace-olympia-staffs-form-new-venture-presents/106383210/|website=The Detroit News|date=October 8, 2017|accessdate=October 8, 2017}} The Palace, despite being 29 years old at its closure, is still in top condition as a sporting and concert venue.{{cite web|url=http://www.freep.com/story/entertainment/2017/08/24/palace-auburn-hills-closing-bob-seger/569388001/|title=Confirmed: Palace of Auburn Hills is closing; Bob Seger to be final event|publisher=}} However, it is located in a northern suburb, relatively far away from the city center, in light of the growing trend of "walkable urbanism" where the Pistons want to grow their fanbase.{{cite web|url=http://www.freep.com/story/money/business/john-gallagher/2017/04/14/detroit-palace-northland-silverdome/100412278/|title=How miscalculation, market trends doomed Palace of Auburn Hills|publisher=}} While there have been no official confirmations as of yet, the Palace is likely to end up demolished, and the site could be redeveloped to accommodate a possible new auto supplier headquarters and research and development parks.{{cite web|url=http://www.freep.com/story/money/business/columnists/2016/11/21/palace-auburn-hills-pistons-development/94234504/|title=After Pistons move, Palace likely faces rapid redevelopment|publisher=}} ==See also== {{Portal|Architecture|Basketball|Metro Detroit|Sports}} *[[DTE Energy Music Theatre]] *[[List of indoor arenas in the United States]] *[[Sports in Detroit]] *[[Tourism in metropolitan Detroit]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Palace of Auburn Hills}} * {{Official website|http://www.palacenet.com}} {{S-start-collapsible|header={{S-sta|et}}}} {{Succession box | before = [[Pontiac Silverdome]] | title = Home of the [[Detroit Pistons]] | years = 1988–2017 | after = [[Little Caesars Arena]]}} {{Succession box | before = none | title = Home of the [[Detroit Shock]] | years = 1998–2009 | after = [[BOK Center]]}} {{Succession box | before = [[DeSoto Civic Center]] | title = Host of [[Slammiversary]] | years = [[Slammiversary (2009)|2009]] | after = [[TNA Impact!
